newsitem.title: USA: U.S. to enforce U.N. sanctions against Libya.
newsitem.headline: U.S. to enforce U.N. sanctions against Libya.

text.p: The United States said on Thursday it would enforce sanctions against Libya after it defied a U.N. ban on flights imposed over the 1988 Lockerbie bombing of Pan Am 103.

"We are investigating these reports to confirm the facts," State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said. "If they are accurate it would be a serious violation of U.N. Security Council resolution 748 which prohibits Libyan aircraft from engaging in international flights. We will pursue this matter in the U.N. Security Council and in the sanctions committee."

Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi defied the U.N. ban by flying in a flotilla of four Boeing 727s to Niger to lead Moslem prayers on Thursday. Burns called on Niger to comply with the U.N. resolution and prevent Gaddafi's plane from departing.

The ban was imposed for Libya's failure to extradite two agents linked to the bombing of the Pan Am flight over Lockerbie, a Scottish village, and four agents linked to the 1989 bombing of a French airliner over Niger.

"The issue here is Pan Am 103," Burns told reporters. "We haven't forgotten the 269 people who were killed on that plane on Dec. 21, 1988. That's why the sanctions are in place against Libya. We have an obligation to the victims' families to enforce these sanctions."

He did not say how the United States would seek to enforce the 1992 sanctions, which call for an air, arms and diplomatic embargo against Libya. A U.S. official said military action was not being considered.
